metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Learn how to make an element visible or not with v-show .
content.html: Learn how to make an element visible or not with v-show.

content.text: v-show is easy to use because the condition is written right in the HTML tag attribute.
content.html: v-show is easy to use because the condition is written right in the HTML tag attribute.

content.text: The v-show directive hides an element when the condition is 'false' by setting the CSS 'display' property value to 'none'.
content.html: The v-show directive hides an element when the condition is 'false' by setting the CSS 'display' property value to 'none'.

content.text: After writing v-show as an HTML attribute we must give a conditon to decide to have the tag visible or not.
content.html: After writing v-show as an HTML attribute we must give a conditon to decide to have the tag visible or not.

content.code: This div tag can be hidden
content.code_html: <div v-show="showDiv">This div tag can be hidden</div>

content.text: In the code above, 'showDiv' represents a boolean Vue data property with either 'true' or 'false' as property value. If 'showDiv' is 'true' the div tag is shown, and if it is 'false' the tag is not shown.
content.html: In the code above, 'showDiv' represents a boolean Vue data property with either 'true' or 'false' as property value. If 'showDiv' is 'true' the div tag is shown, and if it is 'false' the tag is not shown.

content.code: This div tag can be hidden
content.code_html:
<div id="app">
  <div v-show="showDiv">This div tag can be hidden</div>
</div>

<script src="https://unpkg.com/vue@3/dist/vue.global.js"></script>
<script>
  const app = Vue.createApp({
    data() {
      return {
        showDiv: true
      }
    }
  })
  app.mount('#app')
</script>

content.text: The difference between v-show and v-if is that v-if creates (renders) the element depending on the condition, but with v-show the element is already created, v-show only changes its visibility.
content.html: The difference between v-show and v-if is that v-if creates (renders) the element depending on the condition, but with v-show the element is already created, v-show only changes its visibility.

content.text: Therefore, it is better to use v-show when switching visibility of an object, because it is easier for the browser to do, and it can lead to a faster response and better user experience.
content.html: Therefore, it is better to use v-show when switching visibility of an object, because it is easier for the browser to do, and it can lead to a faster response and better user experience.

content.text: A reason for using v-if over v-show is that v-if can be used with v-else-if and v-else .
content.html: A reason for using v-if over v-show is that v-if can be used with v-else-if and v-else.

content.text: In the example below v-show and v-if are used separately on two different <div> elements, but based on the same Vue property. You can open the example and inspect the code to see that v-show keeps the <div> element, and only sets the CSS display property to 'none', but v-if actually destroys the <div> element.
content.html: In the example below v-show and v-if are used separately on two different <div> elements, but based on the same Vue property. You can open the example and inspect the code to see that v-show keeps the <div> element, and only sets the CSS display property to 'none', but v-if actually destroys the <div> element.

content.code:
Div tag with v-show
Div tag with v-if
content.code_html:
<div id="app">
  <div v-show="showDiv">Div tag with v-show</div>
  <div v-if="showDiv">Div tag with v-if</div>
</div>

<script src="https://unpkg.com/vue@3/dist/vue.global.js"></script>
<script>
  const app = Vue.createApp({
    data() {
      return {
        showDiv: true
      }
    }
  })
  app.mount('#app')
</script>

content.text: Fill in the missing part so that Vue toggles the visibility of the <div> tag below for us, depending on the 'lightOn' boolean data property.
content.html: Fill in the missing part so that Vue toggles the visibility of the <div> tag below for us, depending on the 'lightOn' boolean data property.

content.code_html:
<div id="app">
  <div id="lightDiv">
    <div ="lightOn"></div>
    <img src="img_lightBulb.svg">
  </div>
  <button v-on:click=" lightOn =! lightOn ">Switch light</button>
</div>

<script src="https://unpkg.com/vue@3/dist/vue.global.js"></script>
<script>
  const app = Vue.createApp({
    data() {
      return {
        lightOn: false
      }
    }
  })
  app.mount('#app')
</script>
